H0.text: Arthropod is an invertebrate group that has three body segments, a hard exoskeleton, and jointed appendages, and includes spiders and insects.

H1.text: Annelid is an invertebrate group that has three body segments, a hard exoskeleton, and jointed appendages, which includes spiders and insects.

H2.text: Sauropod is an invertebrate group with three body segments, a hard exoskeleton, and jointed appendages, which includes spiders and insects.

H3.text: Crustacean is the invertebrate group that has three body segments, a hard exoskeleton, and jointed appendages, including spiders and insects.

A4.text: Arthropods possess an exoskeleton with a cuticle made of chitin, often mineralised with calcium carbonate, a body with differentiated (metameric) segments, and paired jointed appendages.

A5.text: Arthropods also have two body elements that are not part of this serially repeated pattern of segments, an ocular somite at the front, where the mouth and eyes originated, and a telson at the rear, behind the anus.

A6.text: Other terrestrial arthropods, such as centipedes, millipedes, woodlice, spiders, mites and scorpions, are sometimes confused with insects, since they have a jointed exoskeleton.
